etymologies: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘counterbalance’): from Latin compensat- ‘weighed against’, from the verb compensare, from com- ‘together’ + pensare (frequentative of pendere ‘weigh’)

definitions: give (someone) something, typically money, in recognition of loss, suffering, or injury incurred; recompense

examples.text: payments were made to farmers to compensate them for cuts in subsidies

shortDefinitions: give someone something in recognition of loss

examples.text: he will be richly compensated for his efforts

definitions: reduce or counteract (something unwelcome or unpleasant) by exerting an opposite force or effect

examples.text: the manager is hoping for victory to compensate for the team's dismal league campaign

shortDefinitions: reduce or counteract something unwelcome or unpleasant

definitions: act so as to neutralize or correct (a deficiency or abnormality in a physical property or effect)

examples.text: the output voltage rises, compensating for the original fall

shortDefinitions: act so as to neutralize or correct

definitions: attempt to conceal or offset (a disability or frustration) by development in another direction

examples.text: they put on grandiose airs to compensate for their feelings of worthlessness

shortDefinitions: attempt to conceal or offset disability or frustration by development in another direction
